Account

F

Diagram 2: The teams of Off Premise
National Field Sales: The national field sales department manages sales teams across the
country, interacting directly with customers. It develops strategies to achieve regional sales
goals and monitors the performance of the field team.
Local Key Accounts and Wholesale: The local key accounts and wholesale department manages
relationships with key customers and wholesale channels at the local level. It aims to increase
sales by understanding customer needs and offering them special offers.
National Key Account: The national key account department manages relationships with large
and strategic account accounts. This department works to increase sales volume and ensure
customer satisfaction by developing long-term partnerships.
Trade Marketing: The trade marketing department creates marketing strategies to increase the
visibility of products in retail outlets. It supports sales through promotions, displays, and
campaigns, and analyzes consumer behavior.

sections.section_name:
Company and Sector
Overview of the Company and Sector
sections.content:
Company and Sector
Overview of the Company and Sector
• Red Bull Gıda Dağıtım ve Pazarlama Tic. LTD.
• Off Premise Department
• Address: Ünalan Mh. Libadiye Cd. No:82F Emaar İş Merkezi Kat:20/21 Üsküdar
Istanbul 34700 Turkey
•Web links: https://www.redbull.com/tr-tr
Inspired by functional drinks used in the Far East, Dietrich Mateschitz founded Red Bull in the
mid-1980s. He not only brought a new product to market, but also developed a unique
marketing concept and launched Red Bull Energy Drink in Austria on April 1, 1987. Thus, a new
product category was born - energy drinks. (Red Bull Energy Drink-Company)
According to the company's website, the first can of Red Bull was sold on April 1, 1987. In 1992,
the catchy brand slogan "Winged", "Gives you wings" was advertised. As of the end of 2023, Red
Bull employs 17,848 people in 177 countries (end of 2022: 15,779 in 175 countries). In 2023,
12.138 billion cans of Red Bull were sold, a 4.8% increase compared to the previous year. The
goal is to exceed this figure in 2024 and increase growth.
The company's headquarters is in Austria and in Turkey, it is in Istanbul, but it also has offices in
cities such as Ankara, Izmir and Bursa.
It is the leader in the Energy Drinks category, which is Red Bull's area, and aims to appeal to
consumers with its special Edition series and Sugar Free options in addition to its Regular Red
Bull product.
Red Bull operates in the FMCG sector. FMCG is a product that is sold quickly and at a relatively
low cost. Examples include packaged foods, beverages, convenience foods, toiletries, candies,
cosmetics, over-the-counter medicines, dry goods, and other consumables. Red Bull states its
claim with its products that promise energy and flavor to the consumer in its slogan, “Revitalizes
the body and mind.”
In summary, the basic service that Red Bull provides as a company is to deliver energy drink
products to consumers.
Product varieties vary in Turkey and different countries. The most demanded products offered
to customers in the Turkish market are below.
Red Bull ED
Red Bull Sugar Free
Red Bull Red Edition
Red Bull White Edition
Red Bull Blue Edition
Red Bull Peach Edition
Red Bull Yellow Edition

Executive Summary:
Company's Core Engineering Activities:
The main focus of the company's engineering activities is to increase efficiency, especially in
transportation processes, and to increase profitability by making accurate sales analyses. Since
Red Bull products are not produced in Turkey, the optimization and efficiency of the processes
of shipping, storing and delivering products to customers from the countries where they are
produced are critical for the company. In this context, the company aims to continue its
activities on innovative technologies. Some of the tasks undertaken in this direction are as
follows:
•To produce projects that will increase efficiency by examining existing processes and
applications
• To carry out regular competitor analyses and to make reports in the necessary areas in this
direction.
• To calculate project feasibility
• To determine the steps to be followed during projects and to share them with the teams to be
collaborated with
• To be prepared for problems that may occur during project development processes Actively
using teamwork and communication skills between teams
Internship Activities:
During my internship, I interpreted many reports, especially those from Nielsen, and prepared
them as presentations. At this point, I actively conducted competitor analyses. I analyzed the
impact of specific projects implemented such as our campaign periods on our sales regionally
and product-based. I created customer and month-by-month reports for local chain markets and
wholesale channels on Excel. I also reflected these reports on dashboards on Excel.
Apart from this, I created and published budget files by collecting invoices and sales amounts
received each month in a single file. At the beginning, I thought my internship would be only
data-focused, but I constantly communicated one-on-one with DPMs from 7 regions and every
city. This greatly contributed to the development of my communication skills and problem-
solving abilities.
Due to the importance of the responsibilities given to interns within Red Bull, I was able to
directly contact DPMs and heads of different units such as different sales channels and trade
marketing and ask my questions. I think this is very valuable and I feel very lucky to have
interned in a company that contributed to my development so much.
Key Takeaways:
The most important thing I learned from this internship was that it made me realize that the
FMCG sector is the sector I want to advance in. I am very excited to work for a brand that has a
permanent place in the consumer's life and creates brand love.
If I have to talk about departments, during this time I had the opportunity to get to know the
sales department on different channels and the teams that sales sometimes collaborates with,
such as Brand and Trade Marketing. This experience was a milestone for me, but I believe it
would be better to try out the Marketing department with different internships I will do in the
future and clarify my long-term career plan in this way.

sections.section_name: Professional and Ethical Responsibilities of Engineers
sections.content:
professional group that actively participates in human relations as well as data-driven analysis.
The most widely adopted ethical value is respect for individuals and living things.
Another ethical value is sustainability. In line with this principle, the following practices are
implemented:
•All Red Bull cans are made from 100% recyclable aluminum cans
•More than 85% of can production is done with sustainable “wall-to-wall” production.
•Shipping aluminum cans saves 40% compared to glass bottles.
•95% of our total coolers are made from ECO coolers, and the ECO Cooler uses the same
amount of energy as an average laptop.
•In addition, recyclable glass bottles are used at the headquarters, which are collected at the
end of each day for recycling and never thrown away.
All these processes show the importance of sustainability for Red Bull.

8

Summer Practise Description
Project 1.1: Analysis of Historical Sales Data for SKU Based Sales Forecast
The first step of Project 1 focuses on analyzing sales data for each SKU (Stock Keeping Unit). In
this way, the main goal is to evaluate past performance and create a basis for future sales
forecasts based on these evaluations. The aim is to determine growth trends, weak and strong
points, and thus reach more accurate sales forecasts.
• Performance Indicators: I used monthly data sets via Univera to analyze historical SKU
performance accurately.
• Data and Analysis: I collected and analyzed SKU-based sales data from previous months.
By calculating the monthly performance and growth rates of each SKU, I saw the
performance of the products clearly. Accordingly, I listed low and high performing
products.
• Challenges: It was difficult to work on SKUs with limited data and seasonal variations,
and to interpret the data correctly for some seasonal products such as editions. It was
also necessary to clarify the accuracy of the data in reports from relatively remote
regions such as the Cyprus region.
• Advantages: This analysis helps identify key trends, access specific information such as
which SKU is in higher demand regionally, and thus make future forecasts more reliable.
In addition, this project helps in better resource allocation in production and marketing
in the long run.
This step of the project helped us gain a clear understanding of SKU trends by analyzing past
sales data. This allowed us to optimize inventory levels, production and logistics processes more
efficiently.
Project 1.2: Monthly Sales Forecasts and Comparison
The second step of the project involves collecting monthly sales forecasts for each SKU from the
field sales team and comparing these forecasts with actual sales data. The aim is to improve
forecast accuracy and adjust inventory control plans according to real-time sales performance.
In case of significant differences in the forecast indexes at this point, revision requests can be
made by discussing with the relevant customers' DPMs.
• Performance Indicators: In order to measure the consistency between the forecasted
and actual sales figures, I created index rates separately for each customer by dividing
them by each other.
• Data and Analysis: We expected our DPM and LKAMs to create monthly forecasts using
historical data and market conditions. At this point, I obtained the necessary information
from the forecasting officers in order to make the right analysis in cases where the
region/customer had a special story. Then, I compared these forecasts with actual sales
to evaluate their accuracy and improve future forecasts and shared them with the field.

sections.section_name:
• Challenges: Unforeseen environmental changes and sudden changes in demand, which
can mislead the figures, cause me to get errors or extreme figures in the indexes when
comparing sales in some past months with forecast sales.
• Advantages: This comparison process helped increase the accuracy of sales forecasts
and minimized the risk of stockouts or overproduction, leading to better production
planning and inventory management.
Due to this project, I realized that the company could make more informed decisions about
production and distribution by developing its sales strategies in real time with short-term
forecasting methods.
Project 1.3: Graphical Analysis and Trend Tracking
This step of the project focuses on visually presenting data collected for past and forecast sales
through graphs and charts to track SKU trends and make more data-driven decisions. The goal is
to improve trend analysis by facilitating data interpretation for each customer.
• Performance Indicators: I created a dashboard page based on SKUs to communicate
year-by-year sales trends and identify inconsistencies in forecasts, and created separate
charts where only the months forecasted were compared to the previous year’s actuals.
• Data and Analysis: I made the data captured in the previous stages from the past and
present more intuitive for my department manager and field managers who performed
the forecasts. At this point, I used functions such as slicer, pivot table, charts and VBA in
Excel. Project 1.1: SKU Based Sales Forecast and Trend Analysis
• Challenges: It was difficult to simplify the raw data image when visualizing large data
such as the most demanded SKU. For this reason, I aimed to visualize the desired data
more clearly by making selections with the slicers I added.
• Advantages: Graphical analysis allowed faster and more effective decision making,
allowing customers to adjust their strategies in the coming months accordingly.
Thanks to this step, I learned how graphic and data visualization in sales contribute to a better
understanding of the processes.
Project 2: Creating a Budget File and Calculating Earned Values
This project was created to improve the budget management process of the company's LKA
sales. Earned value calculations are made by comparing incoming invoices and sales data, and
the results are presented to 37 Distribution Partner Managers, 5 Local Key Account Managers
and the sales director with regular reports.
• Performance Indicators: Accuracy of the budget file and ensuring invoice-sales
compatibility. Finding customers with the correct codes in sales and incoming invoices in
the system and correct amounts.
• Data and Analysis: All incoming invoice data was collected in a single Excel and
compared with sales in the system. This data was analyzed with Excel tools such as
SUMIF, VLOOKUP, PIVOT and earned value was calculated.

• Challenges: Failure to receive invoices on time or incomplete sales data created
situations that could lead to errors in calculations. Invoices with incorrect codes did not
match the customers in the system, which caused confusion when calculating the total
amount of incoming invoices.
• Benefits: This process helped make budget management more transparent and efficient,
and costs were controlled more effectively. Each DPM and LKAM saw their end-of-
month status and planned their next month more efficiently.
This step helped me understand that regular budget tracking in sales leads to healthier
strategies in the long run.
Project 3: Strategy Development Using Nielsen Reports
This project aims to analyze regional sales performances using Nielsen reports and create
strategy presentations based on these analyses. The aim is to analyze the market share, sales
volume, and per-liter product price in each region and make presentations and inferences that
will help create strategies to gain competitive advantage.
• Performance Indicators: Interregional market share, sales growth rates, sales volume,
per-liter product prices.
• Data and Analysis: Using data from Nielsen reports, sales performance and store
availability rates with market share in each region are examined. The same analyses are
performed for the three major competitors and strategic planning is made according to
the analysis results.
• Challenges: In some cases, regional data is missing or reports do not arrive on time,
making the analysis process difficult. Especially in regions far from the center, such as
Eastern Anatolia, some in-store information was entered into the systems late or
incompletely, making it difficult to make accurate analyses.
• Benefits: Thanks to this project, regional marketing strategies were developed and it
was aimed to implement special campaigns in these regions and areas by identifying
missing points. With this project, which is continuously carried out in the long term, it is
aimed to further increase Red Bull's effectiveness and competitive power in the market.
Due to this project, I understood the importance of data analysis, including competitor
information, in developing new strategies.

sections.content:
Activity Analysis
PROJECT 1: SKU Based Sales Analysis Report
This project consists of a three stage research that analyzes past sales, collects estimates from
the field, performs estimate analysis, and finally transfers the data to graphics and dashboards.
In the first step, data is plotted and interpreted by considering the effects of seasonal edition
products and environmental factors on past sales on a SKU basis. Here, the status of past sales
on a regional basis is also analyzed. In the second stage, the field sales team is asked to make
estimates for the coming months according to the sales considered in the previous step together
with environmental factors. Here, estimates are also asked for the 250, 355 and 473 ml product
varieties for the Regular RB product. The reason for this is that the most sold SKU variety, Red
Bull Regular, will be put into campaign applications in the future by cooperating with trade
marketing for the products needed in the regions where it is needed. In the third and final step,
all analyzes are put into dashboards, and it is seen in more detail which customers, regions, and
of course SKUs the campaigns mentioned in the previous step will be suitable for, and it is
communicated to the department managers, and the relevant campaigns are created with
consensus. The aim of this project is to increase profitability by optimizing inventory
management and logistics planning with accurate forecasting methods.
Step 1: Analysis of Historical Sales Data for SKU Based Sales Forecast
The first phase of this project focuses on analyzing Red Bull’s SKU (Stock Keeping Unit) based
historical sales data in detail. The aim is to prepare the basis for future sales forecasts by
examining historical sales data and evaluating the effects of seasonal products such as Summer
Edition, Winter Edition and environmental factors. This phase provides important information
about the performance of products over time by calculating growth rates on a SKU basis.
The main goal is to compare performances over time by calculating growth rates for each SKU.
For example, RB-001 (Summer Edition) saw a significant increase in sales during the summer
months, while demand dropped significantly during the winter months. In contrast, RB-002
(Regular Red Bull) showed a stable performance across all four seasons.
The table below shows these differences:

sections.section_name: Step 2: Monthly Sales Forecasts and Comparison
sections.content:
Step 2: Monthly Sales Forecasts and Comparison
This stage aims to create sales forecasts for each SKU for the coming months in light of the data
obtained in the previous step. In this context, the field sales team is asked to make sales
forecasts by considering the historical sales data report and environmental factors provided to
them.
In particular, it is expected that forecasts will increase in the summer months for seasonal
products such as RB-001 (Summer Edition), while the requirements of the period will be taken
into account for other SKUs. The table below shows a comparison between the forecasts made
for last May and the actual sales:
SKU Code Forecasted Sales Actual Sales (May) Deviation (%)
(May)
RB-001 60,000 58,500 -2.5%
RB-002 29,000 28,750 -0.9%
RB-003 85,000 83,000 -2.3%
Table3: Actual-Prediction Index Table
In this example table, the deviations between the big forecast and the actual are largely
consistent, but the opposite can often happen. The process of a customer changing their dealer,
seasonal changes, and even sometimes unpredictable environmental factors can cause the
forecasts to be wrong. I observed the biggest example of this with the earthquake effect in the
forecast-actual index for February 2023.
Apart from this, the most demanded SKU, Regular Red Bull, is available in 3 different ml
quantities. Since the main goal is to maintain and increase sales for each quantity of this SKU,
the sales performances of these products were also analyzed. According to the outputs in the
table below, the ml varieties that can be applied to the activity were determined as 355 and 473
ml, and then, by drawing the sales of only these two ml products for each customer, it was
determined which customer would be included in the campaign for 355 ml and which customer
would be included in the campaign for 473 ml.

Table4: Ml Based Red Bull Regular Analysis Table
As a result, this stage is the strategy stage that aims to make more accurate predictions together
with historical data and environmental factors.
14

12

As seen in this table, RB-001 SKU grew by 16% during the summer months, while RB-002 SKU
experienced a 4% decrease during this period of the year. RB-003 SKU continued to grow
continuously, increasing its sales by 10%. This type of data provides a better understanding of
which products are in seasonal and which are in constant demand, and helps determine which
SKUs have high potential.
I followed the steps below to create this table:
1.First, I pulled the sales from the company's system
2.Then I pivoted the raw data. I created a simple data with monthly sales for each customer.
3.After second step I created the table above from the formats and pulled the sales for each
month with VLOOKUP from the raw data I created in the previous step.
4.Finally, I divided the rates from the first month to the last month that I used for growth rates
and converted them into percentages.
In addition, regional analysis is also critical at this stage. For this reason, I used the regional
summary table format below in the historical sales stage to identify the regions where each
product is strong and weak. For example, sales increase significantly in summer periods in
regions such as the Aegean, Mediterranean, and TRNC. Such seasonal changes require
adaptation of marketing and sales strategies according to regional differences, so their analysis
is important.

sections.section_name: Step 3: Graphical Analysis and Trend Tracking
sections.content:
Step 3: Graphical Analysis and Trend Tracking
This stage includes visualizing all analyzes performed and presenting this data through graphs
and dashboards. The aim is to track sales data and estimates on a SKU basis, monitor
performance and create strategies accordingly.
At this point, I created a dashboard for the years 2023 and 2024, including months, customers,
dealers, all authorities and all SKUs. With the help of slicers in this dashboard, the status of each
SKU in the desired region/month or customer could be tracked separately. In this way, both the
success or failure of past applications was measured and a roadmap for the future was reached.
Graphic1: SKU Based Dashboard
Visualization accelerated and facilitated decision-making processes. In inter-team meetings,
explaining sales with visuals rather than numbers increased communication and efficiency
between teams. After the dashboard, some summary information was put into graphs and text
and a presentation as a status summary was prepared, thus completing the last stage of this
project.
15

Conclusion
Project 1.1: Analysis of Historical Sales Data for SKU Based Sales Forecast
Project 1.2: Monthly Sales Forecasts and Comparison
Project 1.3: Graphical Analysis and Trend Tracking
Project 2: Creating a Budget File and Calculating Earned Values
Project 3: Strategy Development Using Nielsen Reports
During the related activities listed above, I regularly pulled data from the company's system
Univera and made this data more readable in Excel. I actively used various visual and formula-
based features in Excel. I frequently used pivot table and slicer functions; VLOOKUP, SUMIF and
XLOOKUP formulas. Thanks to this, my Excel skills improved considerably. Sometimes I
interpreted the Excel files I created by reflecting them on PowerPoint presentations, which was
a factor that improved my analysis skills. In addition, I gained an idea about how to interpret
data in sales strategies, in other words, the basics of sales development processes.
I saw that engineers working in the sales department generally took an active role in sales
development and data analyst sides. I had the opportunity to get to know Industrial Engineers
working in these positions in departments such as Traditional Channel Sales and Trade
Marketing. However, I also observed that the most preferred place by engineers in the company
is the Supply Chain unit. At this point, all engineers working in the head office work from the
office and do not work in the field. While industrial engineers in the sales department aim to
increase revenue and sales, those in the logistics and operations department try to make the
process of products reaching the consumer more efficient by controlling areas such as
transportation processes and stocks. At this point, I think that this multifaceted job description is
ideal for industrial engineers because in addition to the relationship with data in the sales
department where I am, there is active communication with field teams in 7 regions and
environmental, social and human relations-oriented analyses are made.
Since Red Bull is the leader in its category globally with a significant market share, it is very
important to maintain its competitive power and prevent competitors from surpassing or even
approaching Red Bull sales. For this reason, the company must constantly take appropriate
steps, adapt to changes and attract the attention of the consumer with the right marketing
policies. At this point, Red Bull is also known for its support for extreme sports and aims to
appear before consumers in almost every area with the social activities it participates in. In
addition, attracting consumers' attention in this regard with its care in the field of sustainability
is critical for the company. I believe that Red Bull will maintain its leading position in the sector
with its activity in social areas and creative marketing efforts.

Impact
Economic Impact:
Red Bull is a global beverage brand with over one billion cans sold worldwide. The social
activities it is involved in directly support economic growth while also contributing to various
sectors. For example, sponsoring sports and music events helps these sectors and their
stakeholders grow and sustain their economic gains, while also adding vitality to local
economies.
16

International events, especially the Red Bull Air Race, increase tourism revenues in the cities
where they are held and contribute to the increase in profits of local businesses. In addition, Red
Bull contributes to the survival of these sports and therefore the economic flow from these
sports by supporting extreme sports.
Social Impact:
Red Bull's projects create positive social impacts, especially on the young population. The brand
offers a lifestyle that encourages young people to sports and adventure. With extreme sports,
music festivals and art events, it highlights social values such as movement, courage and
positivity in society. In addition, the projects sponsored by Red Bull allow many young athletes
and artists to show themselves on local and global platforms. This supports the careers of
athletes and artists while also helping them reach an audience. Red Bull also continues to
support the success of young people by contributing to educational projects and programs that
support youth entrepreneurship. Red Bull's initiatives have a significant positive social impact
since they prioritize the needs of its customers while also supporting its workforce. By offering
its employees a wide range of chances for growth and development, the organization raises
employee satisfaction and productivity. These resources foster loyalty throughout the workforce
and aid in the professional and personal growth of staff members. The "trusting its employees"
corporate culture of Red Bull gives people the freedom to design and oversee their own
initiatives. To support its workers' work-life balance, Red Bull also provides flexible work
schedules, remote work options, and a range of health and wellness initiatives. Red Bull also
provides assistance with career development to its staff members. It helps its employees
develop their skills with leadership programs, training seminars and international assignment
opportunities.
Environmental Impact:
Red Bull has placed environmental sustainability at the forefront of its company policies. The
company takes important steps to reduce its carbon footprint. For example, it aims to minimize
its environmental impact by using energy-efficient production facilities and producing recyclable
aluminum cans. In addition, fuel-saving strategies are implemented in Red Bull's logistics
projects, thus reducing carbon emissions. The refrigerators used are of a type that maximize
energy savings. Sustainability efforts also include practices such as more efficient use of energy
resources and waste management in the supply chain. Red Bull places particular emphasis on
renewable energy projects to increase its environmental responsibility.
In summary, projects in which Red Bull takes part both contribute to economic growth,
positively strengthen social values, and act with environmental responsibility. As a global brand,
these projects reach a wide audience and play important roles in terms of sustainability and
social development with the awareness of its responsibility towards its consumers. Drawing
attention with its innovative approach in the energy drink sector, Red Bull continues to be a part
of an economic and social transformation, while also investing in the future with its
environmentally sensitive policies.

Teamwork
During my summer internship, I worked with Gizem, a National Key Account intern, and Altuğ, a
Traditional Channel Sales intern, who started their internships before me. I was also able to get
support when I needed it from Gizem, who is an Analyst from the Traditional Channel, and Arda,
Çağrı and Berkan, who are Local Key Account Managers from my own LKA team.
17

Being able to ask people questions about both my projects and the general company operations
at every stage from the Intern position to the Manager position significantly accelerated my
adaptation process. Especially when I got stuck at a systematic point in my projects, Gizem and I
helped each other and solved the problems. I also benefited a lot from Arda and Berkan's
insights and experiences at the points where I needed to make analysis. Especially when I
needed to analyze environmental impacts and interpret data, their knowledge of the field and
markets helped me a lot. In this way, I increased my efficiency in my projects with the effect of
teamwork in every field. I was able to achieve more effective results in a shorter time.

Self-directed Learning
It is essential for both professional and personal development to adopt a self-directed, lifelong
learning approach that contributes to the ongoing acquisition of knowledge, skills, and
competencies. After giving my internship experience some thought, I've discovered a few crucial
areas that are crucial for professional practice:
Communication: One of the most important competencies I observed during my internship was
communication. Strong and confident communication skills are critical to increased work
efficiency, especially in a professional environment. Both written and verbal communication are
very important, as email is one of the most used tools in corporate communication. Also during
my internship, I realized the importance of clear communication with my remote colleagues,
especially when coordinating tasks and ensuring harmony with people who are not physically
present.
Time Management: Another basic competency that I noticed is time management. Delays in
tasks can negatively affect the functioning of a system, especially in a professional environment
where even hourly data is important, such as sales. Effective time management is necessary to
prioritize tasks correctly and monitor processes efficiently.
Problem Solving Skills: Problem solving skills are another common competency that employees
must have. Especially in times of crisis, it is important to focus on the solution, not the problem,
by providing stress management. Being able to address problems and develop appropriate
solutions regardless of the situation or conditions is critical.
In addition to these common competencies, although they will vary depending on the sector,
department or specific job description, other skills and characteristics that are fundamentally
beneficial for individuals are as follows:
•Ethical Conduct
•Desire for Knowledge
•Professional Conduct
•Leadership Qualities
•Critical Thinking
18

Problem Solving Skills: Problem solving skills are another common competency that employees
must have. Especially in times of crisis, it is important to focus on the solution, not the problem,
by providing stress management. Being able to address problems and develop appropriate
solutions regardless of the situation or conditions is critical.

•Ethical Conduct
•Desire for Knowledge
•Professional Conduct
•Leadership Qualities
•Critical Thinking

During my internship, I worked on multiple complex projects and successfully managed time for
project deadlines. In addition, thanks to effective communication, I enjoyed working with
company employees and expanded my professional network. I was also able to ask for their
support when necessary. At this point, when I encountered difficulties, I was able to expand my
own vision by getting suggestions from many colleagues of different ages and positions and
effectively solve problems.
In addition to these critical competencies, I used my computer programming skills in all projects.
Especially when I did not know and needed help, I did research both online and by reviewing
past company files, and thus I really learned and solved the problems I encountered. This
information allowed me to make the right decisions and to complete my internship by really
learning a lot of new information.
As a result, my internship experience helped me understand the importance of environmental
analysis, problem-solving skills, desire to learn and effective communication skills in achieving
success in both personal and professional development and helped me develop in these areas.

DAY 1
On the first day of my internship, Ms. Ceylin from the company's Human Resources
department first gave me an office tour and introduced me to the people in my department
and the general company operation. The welcome bag in Figure 1 was handled to me. At
this point, I received information about the company's history, history, countries it is located
in globally and its fields of activity. Then, I received an orientation about the departments
and their working procedures and job descriptions. At the end of the training, a general
company tour was given. Then, I had the opportunity to meet my sales managers and Head
of Department in my own department. During the rest of the day, I was taught the Excel
files, presentations and data collection systems that I would use during my internship with
job transfer. In this way, my first day was completed by understanding both the company
operation and the job description.
Figure 1: Welcome Bag
Date Supervisor’s Name Signature
Bilge Özsoy
16.07.2024
21

DAY 2
Today, I received an orientation from IT regarding the use of company computers and
technical equipment. In addition to the use of computers and equipment, I also visited the
meeting rooms and learned how to use the screens in these rooms and the connection
processes for presentations and online meetings. After this orientation, I continued my
department orientation that I started on the first day of my internship. Today, unlike the
previous day, I also received a job and information transfer about Nielsen report files and
presentations. Then, I completed the day by attending the product introduction and brand
value presentation for the new interns.
Date Supervisor’s Name Signature
Bilge Özsoy
17.07.2024
DAY 3
Today, with the activation of my company email and accounts, I started working on my first
project, the budget file. I created a sales report for the first 6 months from the system used
by the company and created 6-month sales by month with the help of the vlookup formula
for 221 customers from the raw data. Then, I divided the invoices by month with the pivot I
created from the 2024 invoice information excel in the archive and determined how much
invoice came to each customer by pulling from the central customer codes. In the last stage,
I multiplied the future invoice budget percentages by the sales amounts to determine the
progress payments and then I determined the budgets created by subtracting the invoice
from the progress payments for each customer. At this point, when I needed confirmation
about clear information such as future invoice budget percentages or branch numbers, I
contacted the field teams from the regions and received verification on behalf of their
customers' information. In this way, I had the opportunity to actively use my communication
skills and problem-solving abilities.
Date Supervisor’s Name Signature
Bilge Özsoy
18.07.2024
22

DAY 4
On the fourth day of my internship, I continued working on the budget file I worked on
yesterday. I worked on a dashboard to visualize the data I created yesterday. My goal here
was to filter the region, dealers and managers and ensure that the data flowed in visual
graphics. I also worked on including the data in the archive into the dashboard so that the
years 2022, 2023 and 2024 could be compared visually. I reached a dashboard view as seen
in Figure 2. The filters I selected with this view allowed me to better understand and
comment on regional, customer group breakdown and monthly sales. In this way, I
understood the importance of data visualization and shared my project, which I had been
working on for 2 days, with my managers and received their feedback.
Figure 2: Dashboard
Date Supervisor’s Name Signature
Bilge Özsoy
19.07.2024
23

DAY 5
In the new week of my internship, I started working on product-based sales as a
continuation of the project I completed last week. At this point, we first determined our
best-selling and most popular product types with our manager. Red Bull has a wide range of
products with its regular products, edition varieties and seasonal special products, and we
decided which products we should choose when working on sku-based reports. Then, as in
the file I created before, I pulled customer-based sales for each customer, but this time I
added our product varieties to the columns and made a report of how much each customer
sold of each type of product. Then, I created a regional summary table and made comments
on which product sold more or less in which region. In addition, we determined the markets
and product categories with low sales and made inferences about what strategies could be
determined in future campaign periods.
Date Supervisor’s Name Signature
Bilge Özsoy
22.07.2024
DAY 6
On the new day of my internship, I was given the task of creating a forecast file by my
manager. I received a file that already collected forecasts for the first 6 months of the year
at the beginning of the year. Then, I created the realized forecast indexes by adding the
realized ones for the first 6 months. The file also contained sales amounts for the 12 months
of 2023. For this reason, I created a separate index by calculating the YTD sales amounts
starting from February for the first 6 months of 2024 and comparing them with the YTDs of
the relevant months of 2023. After making all these arrangements, I completed the file by
opening columns to write the estimates for the remaining months of 2024 and shared the
file with all of our Local Key Account Managers and Regional Managers and asked them to
add their estimates.
Date Supervisor’s Name Signature
Bilge Özsoy
23.07.2024
24

DAY 7
On the 7th day of my internship, I started analyzing Nielsen reports and putting them into
graphs. During this process, I prepared a presentation analyzing factors such as our
company's market share in the sector, our price per liter, and our sales volume. At this point,
I created graphs comparing the total market share of Red Bull and its competitors in Turkey
and the market share in the European region of Istanbul, as shown in figure 3. I also created
similar graphs for the regions of our Local Key Account Managers, namely Ankara, Izmir,
Aydin, Manisa, Bursa, and the Anatolian regions of Istanbul. In this way, I had the
opportunity to comment on the competitors and learn which of our competitors was
progressing better in which region and what strategies could be developed accordingly.
Figure 3: Graphs

Bilge Özsoy

DAY 8
On the 8th day of my internship, I made a more detailed review and evaluated the brand-
based performances and how the products yielded results according to consumer segments.
For example, I made inferences about which age group or income level our products were
popular among consumers and continued the competitor analysis by creating the same
analysis for competitors. At this point, since the analyses I made today could also serve
trade marketing activities in the future, I contacted this team and shared my analyses with
them. At the end of the day, evaluations were made about what actions would be better to
take in which region according to the consumer group we had.
Date Supervisor’s Name Signature
Bilge Özsoy

DAY 9
On the 9th day of my internship, as a result of the meetings we had with my own team and
trade marketing teams the other day, I took on a task where I would collect information
from the field about refrigerators and hot-cold display products. I created an excel file and
collected the information about the refrigerators that needed to be changed in the stores of
our Distribution Partner Manager and Local Key Account Managers in the field. I also
collected the new refrigerator or display requests and tried to establish a communication
bridge between the field and the head office with the file I created. In this way, I expanded
my professional network by improving my communication processes with DPMs in the
regions. I also had the opportunity to expand my knowledge of the refrigerated cabinets and
display areas in stores.
Date Supervisor’s Name Signature
Bilge Özsoy

DAY 10
On the 10th day of my internship, after the task of collecting information from the stores I
had done at the end of last week, we visited Sarıyer Market and Anpa Gross Markets located
on the European Side of Istanbul so that I could physically be present in the stores and
observe the processes. During these visits, we analyzed the stock status in the store,
checked the locations of the cabinets and the placement of the products in the cabinets. At
this point, my manager frequently communicated with the merchandise and sales
representative team working in the field and gave them feedback about the deficiencies and
positive aspects in the stores. In this way, I understood the importance of communication
with the field team in the sales department and how this communication process should be
managed. Then, we took visuals of the stock status and the situation in the stores and
worked on adding them to the monthly field evaluation presentation.
Date Supervisor’s Name Signature
Bilge Özsoy
29.07.2024
DAY 11
Following the field visit we made yesterday, today we attended a presentation specially
prepared for the Merge teams. Since the merge teams of Red Bull and Haribo companies
work together, I had the opportunity to attend the sessions of both companies in this
presentation. I learned about the Perfect Store concept that is aimed to be achieved in
stores within Red Bull. In this concept, stores are evaluated over 85 points and stores are
reached to their total points based on many different factors such as the location of the
products, where the cabinets are located in the store, which product types are in the store,
and special improvement plans and development strategies are applied for stores that
cannot reach the desired level. In the second half of the day, I attended the product
introduction for new members of the team and the presentation of the stores we are in. I
had the chance to learn which local chain markets in Istanbul have the highest demand for
Red Bull products.
Date Supervisor’s Name Signature
Bilge Özsoy
30.07.2024

shipped, and how product tracking is done in the daily process. Figure 4 and Figure 5 show

Excel files that contain daily sales targets and progress with hourly revisions according to
daily actions, and I observed every stage of the field operation of the sales process that I
converted into data at my desk.

DAY 13
On the 13th day of my internship, I had the chance to meet with two markets for customers.
With these meetings with our Istanbul European Local Key Account Manager, I understood
the importance of customer persuasion processes and stress management at critical
moments. During these meetings, we convinced the customer who did not want to buy the
product because he had the product in his hand, to sell the product with a 1 TL discount per
box by putting him into the activity application. While the customer did not want to buy the
product at first due to the activity fee, at the end of the meeting he wanted to buy different
product varieties at the activity price and requested more products. Following these
meetings, I completed the day by preparing a report on the activities and outcomes
implemented so far for 20 key customers in Istanbul and Europe.
Date Supervisor’s Name Signature
Bilge Özsoy
01.08.2024

DAY 14
On the 14th day of my internship, I took on a task related to activity applications that I
prepared a presentation on yesterday. By creating an excel file like the forecast file I had
created the previous days, we collected the customers and activity information they wanted
to enter the activity from DPM and LKAM for the next two months. I also shared my files
with the field in order to support the processes of determining the customers who will enter
the activity with the effect of the Nielsen reports and sales analyses I have created so far. At
the end of the day, after collecting all the data, we reviewed the campaign suggestions in
the file with our Head Bilge Bey and the file reached its final form in line with his revisions. In
this way, I had the opportunity to gain from his past experiences on important points in the
campaign processes.
Date Supervisor’s Name Signature
Bilge Özsoy
02.08.2024
29

DAY 15
On the 15th day of my internship, I attended the Competition Board training that our
company required us to attend, together with all sales department employees. In the
Competition Board training, I learned the basic principles of competition law and the
applications of these rules in the FMCG sector. In particular, I understood the regulations
introduced to protect competition in the markets and the measures taken against
competition violations. I learned how situations such as cartels, monopolies and unfair
competition affect companies' growth strategies and how such situations are detected. I
also realized that companies are obliged to notify the Competition Board in merger and
acquisition processes and how these processes should be taken into consideration in the
sales department.
Date Supervisor’s Name Signature
Bilge Özsoy
05.08.2024

DAY 16
With the information I gathered from the field for the campaigns we've been running
over the last several months, I made an Excel file and added graphs to show the
outcomes. I began to examine the campaign's overall effects during this process.
Initially, I looked at which products and stores sold more by comparing the sales
numbers before and after the promotion. I paid close attention to how the advertising
influenced particular product categories and geographical areas. I also made an effort
to comprehend the campaign's impact on the consumer by doing an analysis based on
customer segmentation. In this analysis, I assessed the impact on customer loyalty and
brand awareness in addition to sales success. This meant I had to use my analysis
skills from a broader perspective.
Date Supervisor’s Name Signature
Bilge Özsoy

presentation including a year-by-year comparison of Red Bull's key customer sales.
Then, in the second half of the day, we attended the launch event of our new product
"Red Margarita", organized under the leadership of the On Premise team, and listened
to the journey of the product from the idea stage to its arrival on the shelves. In this
way, I had the opportunity to get to know the On Premise team and its members more
closely.
